citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There were 5 guinea pigs observed with health conditions requiring treatment in accordance with the Program of
Veterinary Care or consultation with the attending veterinarian. A brown and white adult guinea pig in pen 3 had a raised,
darkened area of skin approximately 1 cm in size above the bottom of the right back foot and was limping. The licensee
had not observed the health condition and was not administering any treatments. There were 4 guinea pigs with lumps
under the chin. A white and tan adult guinea pig in Pen 7 had a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor
adult guinea pig in pen 10 had a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor adult guinea pig in Pen 13 had
a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor adult guinea pig in Pen 14 had a lump under the chin
approximately 4 cm in size. The licensee had observed the health conditions but was not administering any treatments in
these 4 guinea pigs. All of the animals were bright and alert and in good body condition.
Swellings in the neck and abnormalities of the feet or legs can be indications of disease or injury, can be painful, affect the
overall health and well-being of the animal, and may require treatment with antibiotics or other medications. Failure to
seek proper diagnosis and treatment for disease may result in pain to the animals, worsening of the condition, and
possible spread to additional animals if the condition is contagious.
The licensee must communicate with the attending veterinarian to evaluate these animals and determine an appropriate
plan for diagnosis and treatment.
This inspection was a site approval inspection.
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License.
Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There were 5 guinea pigs observed with health conditions requiring treatment in accordance with the Program of 
Veterinary Care or consultation with the attending veterinarian. A brown and white adult guinea pig in pen 3 had a raised, 
darkened area of skin approximately 1 cm in size above the bottom of the right back foot and was limping. The licensee 
had not observed the health condition and was not administering any treatments. There were 4 guinea pigs with lumps 
under the chin. A white and tan adult guinea pig in Pen 7 had a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor 
adult guinea pig in pen 10 had a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor adult guinea pig in Pen 13 had 
a lump under the chin approximately 2 cm in size. A tricolor adult guinea pig in Pen 14 had a lump under the chin 
approximately 4 cm in size. The licensee had observed the health conditions but was not administering any treatments in 
these 4 guinea pigs. All of the animals were bright and alert and in good body condition. 
Swellings in the neck and abnormalities of the feet or legs can be indications of disease or injury, can be painful, affect the 
overall health and well-being of the animal, and may require treatment with antibiotics or other medications. Failure to 
seek proper diagnosis and treatment for disease may result in pain to the animals, worsening of the condition, and 
possible spread to additional animals if the condition is contagious. 
The licensee must communicate with the attending veterinarian to evaluate these animals and determine an appropriate 
plan for diagnosis and treatment. 
 
This inspection was a site approval inspection. 
 
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License. 
 
Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
